sentence: Software stocks have been punished during the recent selloff.
And Salesforce (CRM), despite its success, hasn’t escaped the wrath.
But Salesforce’s fortunes can immediately change with impressive financial results.
The software-as-a-service and cloud giant is set to report first quarter fiscal 2020 earnings results after the closing bell Tuesday.
Its shares have fallen more than 8% over the past thirty days.
Investors who have waited for a better entry point can do well here, given the company’s projected earnings growth rate of 27.5% annually over the next five years.
Salesforce’s customer relationship management services are a must-have for many companies looking to add capabilities such as sales, marketing, e-commerce and analytics.
“Companies across every industry, in every geography have a mandate to digitally transform their businesses and are turning to Salesforce as a strategic partner,” Co-CEO Keith Block recently said.
As such, Salesforce’s guidance and its billings forecast will be closely watched on Tuesday to assess the immediate direction of the stock.
For the quarter that ended April, Wall Street expects the San Francisco-based company to earn 61 cents per share on revenue of $3.68 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earnings came to 52 cents per share on revenue of $3.01 billion.
For the full year, ending February 2020, earnings of $2.69 per share would decline 2% year over year, while full-year revenue of $16.1 billion would rise 21% year over year.
Strong revenue and earnings growth projections are par for the course for the enterprise cloud giant, which has topped or matched the Street’s earnings estimates in nineteen straight quarters.
In the fourth quarter, reported in March, the company beat on both the top and bottom lines.
Q4 revenue of $3.60 billion beat Street forecast for $3.56 billion, while adjusted EPS of 70 cents per share easily topped the 55 cents per share analysts were looking for.
Salesforce continues to deliver where it matters the most despite the industry being highly competitive, where rivals such as Adobe (ADBE) and Oracle (ORCL) are growing market share.
The company’s growth in recent quarters has been driven, in part, by its global expansion efforts.
Salesforce is looking to capitalize on the digital transformation currently being embraced by businesses of all sizes and industries.

Salesforce’s ability to offer integrated solutions, combined with strategic partnerships with tech giants such as Amazon (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL), has given it a key competitive advantage in terms of its international reach.
That said, the growth rate has begun to slow.
The fourth quarter results delivered earnings growth of 23% with revenue growth of 26%.
This compares to its three-year growth where earnings have grown at a rate of 45% per year, while revenues have grown at a rate of 26%.
The deceleration in growth is understandable and normal for a company that has pioneered the cloud market.
But it does suggest that the stock’s breathtaking performance must also come down.

As such, Salesforce’s guidance and its billings forecast will be the most closely watched aspects of Tuesday’s report as it will determine the extent to which the company can achieve its goal of reaching revenue of $20 billion by 2022.
